summary: This is a Metropolitan Correctional Center clinical nurse's memorandum detailing the medical emergency response to inmate Jeffrey Epstein on August 10, 2019. It describes finding Epstein unresponsive in his cell with signs of neck trauma and the subsequent unsuccessful resuscitation efforts before his transport to a local ER.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate who was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, with CPR in progress and signs of trauma around the neck.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive in Cell
events.description: At approximately 6:33 a.m., inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive on the floor of his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. He was cold, had circumferential bruising around the neck, fixed and dilated pupils, and no palpable pulses. CPR was initiated by correctional officers and continued by medical staff.

events.title: Resuscitation Attempt and Transport
events.description: CPR continued, an AED was applied with no shock advised. Epstein was transported to the Health Services Unit treatment room and later to a local emergency room with CPR in progress. EMS and paramedics arrived, intubated him, administered epinephrine, but cardiac monitoring showed asystole (no cardiac activity).

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, New York
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at approximately 6:33 a.m. on August 10, 2019.
The report notes 'circumferential Bruising around the neck' as an observed condition upon arrival.
Despite continuous CPR and advanced life support interventions by correctional officers, MCC medical staff, and EMS, Epstein showed no cardiac activity (asystole) and was transported to a local ER.
The document is a contemporaneous medical record from the day of Epstein's death.
